sense.name: move or cause to shudder or vibrate
sense.examples: The chemist shook the flask vigorously. His hands couldn't stop shaking. He was shaken from his dreams. Shake the salt out of the salt shaker. He shook off his water logged boots. I shook my piggy bank but all that came out was a paper clip. The 6.2 magnitude quake shook the densely populated province. A child 's brain and body can be injured when he or she is shaken.

sense.name: make unstable, undermine, cause to waver, challenge
sense.examples: My faith has been shaken. The bad news shook her hopes. The civil war shook the country. I'm all shook up! The sinister and surreal events of the night shook him up so badly that he resigned.

sense.name: make a communicative gesture
sense.examples: She shook her finger at the naughty students. Teach your horse to shake his head yes and no. They ought not shake hands with people while they are infected. Don't shake your fist at me. Shake, shake, shake, shake your booty.

sense.name: get rid of
sense.examples: I couldn't shake the feeling that I was being watched. He tried to shake the car that was following him. He shook off his image as one of international football's conservatives. Daughter Barbara shook off her Secret Service escort.

sense.name: shuffle and reorganize
sense.commentary: Includes: SHAKE UP (specific. general sense of challenge or undermine is sense 2)
sense.examples: The corporation shook up its financial staff after the buyout. As rumored , Microsoft shook up Windows development by putting Steven Sinofsky in charge.
